snippet: An acrostic about a philosopher king from Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
abstract: An acrostic about a philosopher king from Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon.
lead_paragraph: VARIETY PUZZLE — It’s curious that two of the most memorable villains in fiction share a fondness for Marcus Aurelius. In Richard Connell’s 1924 short story “The Most Dangerous Game,” General Zaroff, the unhinged sophisticate who hunts humans on his island, unwinds at the end of the night with a bottle of chambertin and the writings of Aurelius. In “The Silence of the Lambs,” Hannibal Lecter quotes from The Meditations during a cellblock interrogation: “First principles, Clarice. Simplicity. Read Marcus Aurelius. Of each particular thing ask: what is it in itself? What is its nature? What does he do, this man you seek?”
